message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 protein is also known as complement receptor 2, and it binds to the Epstein-Barr virus. Therefore, a mutation in the gene encoding for CD21 protein is most likely to prevent infection with Epstein-Barr virus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21, also known as the Epstein-Barr virus receptor, is an entry receptor for Epstein-Barr virus. Therefore, a mutation in the gene encoding for CD21 protein is most likely to prevent infection with Epstein-Barr virus. The other options do not use CD21 as an entry receptor.

We refer to PubMed articles on medicine for help. CD21 protein, also known as complement receptor 2, is a receptor for Epstein-Barr virus. Therefore, inducing a mutation in the gene encoding for CD21 protein is most likely to prevent infection with Epstein-Barr virus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 protein acts as a recepto on B cells for Epstein-Barr virus, so a mutation in this gene is most likely to prevent infection with Epstein-Barr virus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 is also known as the Epstein-Barr virus receptor, so a mutation in the CD21 gene is likely to prevent infection with Epstein-Barr virus. All other options are not related to the CD21 protein.

We refer to scientific articles on medicine for help. CD21 protein is a receptor for Epstein-Barr virus, so a mutation in its gene is most likely to prevent infection with Epstein-Barr virus. All other options do not use CD21 protein as a receptor for infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 protein is the receptor for Epstein-Barr virus, so a mutation in the gene encoding for CD21 protein would most likely prevent infection with Epstein-Barr virus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CD21 protein is a receptor for Epstein-Barr virus, which binds to B cells and epithelial cells of the nasopharynx. Therefore, a mutation in the gene encoding for CD21 protein would prevent infection with Epstein-Barr virus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 protein is a receptor for Epstein-Barr virus, therefore a mutation in its gene would likely prevent infection with that virus. The other viruses are not known to bind to CD21 protein.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 is a receptor for Epstein-Barr virus, therefore a mutation in the gene encoding for CD21 is most likely to prevent infection with Epstein-Barr virus. It has no effect on Rhinovirus, Cytomegalovirus, or Parvovirus.
